Amazon EBS Service uh so Amazon ec2 and Amazon EBS are offered in a number of
locations around the globe today uh Amazon web services has seven public regions we have several regions in North
America uh we have a region in South America one in the EU Singapore and Japan uh and we also have a gov Cloud
region as well um within each region uh we provide uh uh a number of
availability zones or azs an availability zone is a distinct location
that's engineered to be insulated from failures in other azs uh and they provide inexpensive low network
connectivity to other A's in that region so you can when launching Amazon ec2
instance in an in availability Zone you can utilize separate azs to protect your applications from failure uh in a single
location so so what is Amazon ec2 Amazon ec2 provides uh resizable compute
capacity into AWS Cloud it enables you to elastically scale up and scale down
the amount of compute resources that you need to run your workload uh and you can do this based on the demand internally
within your organization or based on the demand of your customers it allows you then to avoid the large Capital
expenditures that typically come with purchasing Hardware infrastructure because you only have to pay for what
you use the Amazon ECT compute instances are fully under your control so you're giving you're given an instance with a
Bas operating system whether it's Linux or Windows and you can uh configure the instance as you need with the
applications that you need to to run we provi provide full flexibility by providing not only a number of different
operating system choices but also allowing you to tailor the the uh your
application to the to the instance that you need based on based on the cost so you're able to uh for example spin up an
ec2 instance with uh a low amount of CPU or a high amount of CPU or there's also
options for for different memory uh different memory allocations to the instance as well this flexibility then
allows you to to lower your cost again to tailor against your your particular workload requirements in terms of in
terms of pricing we offer a number of different options so we offer on demand pricing for ec2 we also have a model
called reserved instances or RIS RIS allow you to purchase a a a number of
instances upfront and Reserve instances up front allowing you to then pay a
lower hourly cost when you actually need them and finally we have spot instances which allow our customers to bid on
unused ec2 capacity and run those instances for as long as their bid price
exceeds the current spot price spot instances are really ideal if you have flexibility in when your applications
can run and they allow you to significantly lower your costs Amazon ec2 is designed for high reliability and
it's backed by a 99.95% availability
SLA the next service I want to cover today is Amazon EBS or our elastic Block
store offering Amazon EB s provides Block Level storage volumes uh for use
with ec2 providing low latency access to your applications running on Amazon ec2
EBS volumes persist independently independently from the instance so if you terminate your ec2 instance your
volume will continue to to persist they're easy to use so it's as easy as creating an EBS volume specifying the
size of that volume and attaching that volume to your instance they allow you to we allow you to flexibly provision
these volumes as you can spin up a number of s volumes attach them to your to in to your instances you can then
detach those volumes and attach them to other instances that need access to that data like our Amazon ec2 service EBS
with EBS you only pay for the resources that you need and and EBS offers a high level of reliability 99.5 to
99.9% durability EBS also provides you with the capability to take Point intime
backups of your of your EBS volumes and store those snapshots in Amazon S3 or
durable internet storage service you can then access those snapshots in subsequently creating uh EBS volumes
from those snapshots so now that I've given an overview of our EBS and our ec2
services I'd now like to to get into some of the capabilities that we've launched in the last month the first
capability I'd like to cover is what we're calling EBS provisioned iops EBS provisioned iops is a new type
of volume that we introduced several weeks ago to deliver predictable high performance performance for your IO
intensive workloads an EBS the way a provisioned iops volume works is you
create an EBS volume you specify the size of the volume that you want to create and you specify the number of
iops that you want to get from that volume and EBS will for the lifetime of that volume deliver that level of iops
to your application you can provision a volume for up to 1,000 iops today and will be increasing that limit over time
and you can then attach multiple volumes to your ec2 instance and stripe across those volumes to deliver thousands of
iops to your application running on ec2 the important thing to note is not just the level of iops that you're going to
get from your volume but also the consistency in those in those iops so we spoken to a number of customers who have
told us that for their random database IO workloads it's not only the scale of
iops that's important but also the consistency at which they get those iops to their application the consistency and
the latency performance and So Pro uh provisioned Ops is really designed to deliver that consistent level of
performance you can use our Amazon cloudwatch monitoring service to monitor
the metrics of your of your volume whether it's throughput bandwidth latency on a one minute basis to really
allow you to react to any changes in your volume performance I'd like to give an overview
of of of our provisioned Ops offering and compare it to our standard volume offering just to give you additional
context on when you'd want to use one type of volume versus another type of volume so stand standard volumes are
pre-existing volume type are really designed for applications with moderate or bursty IO workloads so for example
boot volumes are a great use case for for your standard uh for standard volumes uh EBS provides the ability to
to create a bootable drive for your ec2 instance and for these bootable drives when you're starting up an ec2 instance
there's typically a burst that occurs from the volume at at at runtime so so boot volumes are a great use case
standard volumes on average deliver about 100 iops for customer workloads and they provide a best effort ability
to burst to hundreds of iops our provisioned iops work uh offering as I mentioned is really designed for more IO
intensive workloads such as databases and it's really around providing consistent high performance as I
mentioned you can you can provision up to a thousand iops today uh and you can stripe across multiple volumes to
deliver thousands of iops to your ec2 instance I'll Now cover some things you can do to optimize uh your provision
doops volume performance for your database workloads the first thing you can do is utilize uh EBS optimized
instances so EBS optimized instances is a new feature that we came out with in conjunction with our provisioned Ops uh
volume announcement EBS optimized instances allow you to fully utilize the iops that you provision on an EBS volume
so they allow you to create an ec2 instance that delivers dedicated throughput between your instance and
your EBS volume these these optimized instances today are offered on M1 large
M1 extra large and M24 extra large instances will be supporting additional instances over time the M1 large
delivers 500 megabits per second dedicated throughput between your instance and volume and the uh M1 extr
large delivers a th000 megabits per second so an example of why you might want to use an EBS optimized instance
let's say you're using uh your your your workload is utilizing the provision doops volume and you're reading and
writing from your application to your to your volume and let's say you're also uh reading uh sending data over the network
to your ec2 instance from another location you don't want that that data transfer to your ec2 instance to impact
the performance and throughput that you're getting between your instance and your EBS volume so by utilizing this dedicated throughput between your
instance and EBS you can assure ensure maximum consistency in your workload running on EBS and so that's why when
when attached to EBS optimized instances provisioned iops volumes are designed to deliver within 10% of the iops
performance that you provision 99.9% of the time so if youve provisioned an EBS
volume for a thousand iops you'll get at least 900 iops from that volume
99.9% of the time the next thing to consider when utilizing a provisioned iops volume is
the io size of the reads and rights that you're performing to that volume provision diaps volumes are designed to
process reads and wrs in IO sizes of 16 kilobytes or less so if your application
is is is reading and writing data at IO sizes of 4 kilobytes or 16 kilobytes and
you've provisioned a volume for 1,000 iops you'll get consistently 1,000 iops from that volume if your application on
the other hand is is reading and writing data at 32 kilobyte block sizes then
you'll you'll you'll on a consistent basis get 500 iops uh from that volume
and the reason is because when when EBS volume receives a 30 2 kilobyte block size it splits that up into 16 K
kilobyte blocks and process processes each of those blocks independently you
can utilize Amazon Cloud watches one minute metrics to Monitor throughput to Monitor the io sizes what we've
typically found is that random database workloads typically operate at an IO size of 8K 16k 4K but it is something to
be aware of another thing to to to be aware of when utilizing provision iops volumes is
to ensure that the Q length or Q depth meets the requirements of that volume so a q length is the number of pending IO
requests from your application to your volume many times you can configure your database to the Q length that you need a
provision iops volume must maintain an average Q length of one for every 200 iops you provision so for example if you
if you've provisioned a volume for a thousand iops then you'd want to have a Q depth of on average uh five per minute
and again you can use cloudwatch to monitor the Q depth this really ensures that the EBS volume in order to in order
to um deliver on the iops that it's been provisioned for it ensures that it's getting the necessary IO requests from
your application to do so a couple other things to keep in mind
um when you're when you're taking a snapshot this can impact the rate of iops you're getting from your volume while your snapshot's pending uh and
then finally uh for newly created volumes you want to warm up your Vol volume first before you place it into
production um so for example if you're running a uh a benchmarking application to try out
provisioned iops volumes you may want to run your benchmarking application first to just read and write all the data on
your volume to to warm it up and then run it for real um on the on the subject of benchmarking applications uh we've
